Gallons per BarrelThe following Crude Oil in Bulk of 42 U.S. Gallons per Barrel fwith conversion of Net Bbls. to Net Tons')The following Crude Oil in Bulk of 42 U.S. Gallons per BarrelWe have been going into the matter of whether the Bahrein Petroleum Company Royalty and Gauging returns (the last of which were sent to us under cover of your Printed Letter No. P. Z. 1170/37 of the 22nd February) were any longer of immediate interest to us. We have come to the conclusion that there is no longer any need for us to receive them. If you see no objection, could you therefore very kindly arrange for them not to be sent to us in future in the ordinary course? • Glaus on, Esq,No 329-28/5• The Political j 'fil. 2. BP A Nr ‘ SErCopy of letter No♦PA-610 dated the 6th August 1336 from the Chief Local Representative, The Bahrain Petroleum Company Limited, Bahrain, to His Britannic Majesty’s Political Agent, Bahrain* i ’ / ‘ j > , , Enclosed please find Royal|ty Tickets Nos.R.5, R.6-A, R.6-B, S.8, S.B-A, S.10-A and 6.10-B. You will observe that three of the tickets are split into 11 A*” &nd T, B l! portions, and that the amount of oil upon which royalty is payable on each of these three particular Z 2 CJ runs is the total of the two tickets (A plus B) * Howev r, the total amounts appear on the ”3” tickets, before the amounts already accrued on the ,? A” tickets are deducted. Our reason for ’’splitting” these deliveries is that, in order to obtain an accurate accounting on crude oil produc d, we are compelled to fix a time when one month ends, and a new month commences. As you will notice, the time is 5 A.M. on the first day of the Calendar month. As far as Shaikh ^ir Hamad is concerned, this procedure will make no difference whatever to the total amount of royalty payable to the Bahrain Authorities. He will, however, be assured of getting the royalty on all oil delivered to the Refinery and ^itra tanks during the period in whicn it was physically pumped into those tanks, without waiting until an official high gauge is taken - sometiEes several aaya ^tar the close of an accounting, or royalty, period.■ H.M’s Secretary of State for India, London. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: Coll 30/174(1) 'Bahrein Oil: Monthly returns of royalties.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the inside front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 489; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains monthly royalty delivery tickets issued by the Bahrain Petroleum Company (BAPCO), for the period June 1936 to December 1938 inclusive. The tickets give figures for net tons of crude oil delivered to the BAPCO refinery, on which royalty was paid to the Government of Bahrain (referred throughout as Bahrein). The tickets are witnessed by the State Engineer (and Assistant State Engineer) of the Government of Bahrain. The file also contains summaries of oil deliveries upon which gross royalty was accrued, for the period September to December 1938; some BAPCO correspondence relating to the tickets; and covering letters from the Political Agency, Bahrain to the India Office.The file includes a divider, which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
